titleStmt.title: A declaration from Sir Thomas Fairfax and the army under his command as it was humbly tendered to the Right Honourable the Lords and Commons assembled in Parliament : as also to the Honourable the Lord Mayor, aldermen, and Common-Councell of the city of London : concerning the just and fundamentall rights and liberties of themselves and the kingdome : with some humble proposals and desires.
titleStmt.author: Fairfax, Thomas Fairfax, Baron, 1612-1671.

titleStmt.title: A declaration from Sir Thomas Fairfax and the army under his command as it was humbly tendered to the Right Honourable the Lords and Commons assembled in Parliament : as also to the Honourable the Lord Mayor, aldermen, and Common-Councell of the city of London : concerning the just and fundamentall rights and liberties of themselves and the kingdome : with some humble proposals and desires.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A DECLARATION FROM Sir Thomas Fairfax, AND The Army under his Command.
As it was humbly tendered to the Right Honourable the Lords and Commons AÅ¿Å¿embled in Parliament: As alÅ¿o to the Honourable the Lord Mayor, Aldermen, and Common-Councell of the City of London.
Concerning the juÅ¿t and fundamentall Rights and Liberties of themÅ¿elves and the Kingdome: With Å¿ome humble PropoÅ¿als and DeÅ¿ires.
PRinted by the Å¿peciall appointment of His Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, and Souldiery of the Army under his Command.
St. Albons, June 14. 1647.
Signed by me, JOHN RUSHVVORTH.
Imprinted at London, for L. Chapman, and L. Blacklocke. 1647.

div.head: A Declaration from his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, and the Army under his Command, humbly tendered to the PARLIAMENT, concerning the juÅ¿t and fundamentall Rights and Liberties of themÅ¿elves and the Kingdome, with Å¿ome humble propoÅ¿alls and deÅ¿ires.
div.p:
THat we may be no longer the diÅ¿-Å¿atisfaction of our friends, the Å¿ubject of our enemies malice to worke jealoÅ¿ies and miÅ¿-repreÅ¿entations upon, and the Å¿uÅ¿pition if not aÅ¿toniÅ¿hment of many in the Kingdome in our late or preÅ¿ent tranÅ¿-actions and conduct of buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, we Å¿hall in all faithfulneÅ¿Å¿e and cleareneÅ¿Å¿e profeÅ¿Å¿e, and declare unto you thoÅ¿e things which have of late portracted and hindered our diÅ¿banding, the preÅ¿ent grievances which poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e our Army and are yet unremedied, with our deÅ¿ire as to the compleat Å¿ettlement of the liberties and peace of the Kingdome, which is that bleÅ¿Å¿ing of God then which nothing is more deare to us, or more precious in our thoughts, we having hitherto thought all our preÅ¿ent injoyments, whether of life or livelihood, or
neareÅ¿t relations, a price but Å¿ufficient to the purchaÅ¿e of Å¿o rich a bleÅ¿Å¿ing, that we, and all the freeborne people of this Nation may Å¿it downe in quiet under our Vines, and under the glorious adminiÅ¿trations of JuÅ¿tice and RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e, and in full poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of thoÅ¿e fundamentall rights and liberties without which we can have little hopes as to humane conÅ¿iderations, to enjoy either any comforts of life, or Å¿o much as life it Å¿elfe, but at the pleaÅ¿ures of men, ruling meerely according to will and power. It cannot be unknowne what hath paÅ¿Å¿ed betwixt the Parliament and the Army as to the Å¿ervice of Ireland; by all which together with the like proceedings againÅ¿t the Army, in relation to their Petition and grievances, all men may judge what hath hindered the Army from a ready ingagement in that Å¿ervice, and without further Account or Apology as to that partieular, then what thoÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ages and proceedings themÅ¿elves already made publike doe afford; we doe appeale to your Å¿elves, whether thoÅ¿e courÅ¿es to which the Parliament hath by the deÅ¿ignes and practice of Å¿ome been drawne, have rationally tended to induce a cheerefull and unanimous undertaking of the Army to that Å¿ervice, or rather breake and pull the Army in peeces with diÅ¿contents and diÅ¿honour, and to put Å¿uch diÅ¿obligations and provocations upon it as might drive it into diÅ¿temper, and indeed diÅ¿courage both this Army and other Souldiers from any further engagement in the Parliaments Å¿ervice: And we wiÅ¿h all men would with us upon the whole carriage Å¿eriouÅ¿ly conÅ¿ider, whether in the intentions of thoÅ¿e who have by falÅ¿e informations, and miÅ¿-repreÅ¿entations
put the Parliament upon Å¿uch wayes: The timely and effectuall reliefe of Ireland Å¿eeme really to have been intended, or rather (with the breaking or disbanding of this Army) to draw together or raiÅ¿e Å¿uch other Forces, and of Å¿uch a temper as might Å¿erve to Å¿ome deÅ¿perate and deÅ¿tructive deÅ¿ignes in England, which (beÅ¿ides the probable Å¿uÅ¿pitions from their carriage of the buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, we have before hand, in the tranÅ¿action thereof, had more then hints of Å¿uch a deÅ¿igne, by cleare expreÅ¿Å¿ions to that purpoÅ¿e, from many of thoÅ¿e Officers of the Army, that have been perÅ¿waded, and appeared moÅ¿t forward to ingage for Ireland on the termes propoÅ¿ed. And that Å¿uch a deÅ¿igne hath all along been driven, Å¿eemes now too evident by the preÅ¿ent diÅ¿poÅ¿ing of thoÅ¿e Forces that have been ingaged for Ireland) by the indeavour of Å¿ome to gaine a power from the Parliament, of ordering thoÅ¿e Forces for Å¿ome Service in England, and by the private liÅ¿tings of men for Å¿ervice here, without any publique Authority of Parliament; And (all this) by the Å¿ame perÅ¿ons who have all along appeared moÅ¿t active and violent in the late proceedings againÅ¿t the Army.

As to the juÅ¿t diÅ¿contents and diÅ¿-Å¿atisfaction of the Army, in relation to their grievances, and their noncomplyance to the late Orders for Souldiers disbanding by peece-meale, before more full and equall Å¿atisfaction were given to the whole; We deÅ¿ire you to looke back to the Papers already publiÅ¿hed of the grievances themÅ¿elves, the Narrative of the Officers, and to the latter Papers from the Generall Councell of Warre at Bury, and the late generall Rendezvouze neare New-market; and (we thinke your late reÅ¿uming the conÅ¿ideration of thoÅ¿e things (as to a further Å¿atisfaction) doth much juÅ¿tifie the deÅ¿ires and proceedings of the Army in thoÅ¿e paÅ¿t particulars hitherto. And though (had we
ã1 page duplicateã
ã1 page duplicateã
(upon our firÅ¿t addreÅ¿Å¿es) for our undoubled Rights and dues) found a free and candid reception, with a juÅ¿t conÅ¿ideration, and a reaÅ¿onable Å¿atisfaction, or at leaÅ¿t an ingenious AnÅ¿wer therein; We Å¿hould have been eaÅ¿ily Å¿atisfiable to have abated or forborne much of our dues, and not to have inquired into, or conÅ¿idered (Å¿o farre as we have) either the poÅ¿Å¿ibilities there are for more preÅ¿ent Å¿atisfaction of Arreares, or the credit of future Å¿ecurities propoÅ¿ed; yet Å¿ince upon thoÅ¿e former addreÅ¿Å¿es, we have found Å¿uch hard dealing (as in the Å¿aid Papers is Å¿et forth, and thoÅ¿e additionall (though hitherto but partiall Å¿atisfaction) coming Å¿o hardly as they have, we finde no obliging reaÅ¿ons in the leaÅ¿t, to decline or recede from what is our due, but rather Å¿till to adhere unto our deÅ¿ires of full and equall Å¿atisfaction in all the things mentioned in the aforeÅ¿aid Papers, not onely in behalfe of our Å¿elves and the Army, but alÅ¿o of the whole Souldiery thorow out the Kingdome, who have concurred, or Å¿hall concurre with us in the Å¿ame deÅ¿ires, and to all our former deÅ¿ires. As Souldiers we cannot but adde this, wherein we finde our Å¿elves Å¿o neerly concerned in point of JuÅ¿tice and Reputation, that more care, and a Å¿tricter courÅ¿e may be taken for good, all Articies granted upon Å¿urrendors, according to the true intent and meaning of them; as alÅ¿o for remedy and reparation, in caÅ¿e of any breach (and this) without thoÅ¿e delayes which divers have found as prejudiciall to them, or more then if they had been totally denied the performance of them. Nor will it now (we hope) Å¿eeme Å¿trange or unÅ¿eaÅ¿onable to rationall and honeÅ¿t men, who conÅ¿ider the conÅ¿equence of our preÅ¿ent caÅ¿e, and their own and the Kingdoms, as well as our future concernments in point of right, freedome, peace and Å¿afety, if from a deepe Å¿ence of the high conÅ¿equence of our preÅ¿ent caÅ¿e, both to
our Å¿elves (in future) and all other people, we Å¿hall before Disbanding proceed in our owne and the Kingdoms behalfe to propound, and plead for Å¿ome proviÅ¿ion for our and the Kingdoms Å¿atisfaction, and future Å¿ecurity in relation to thoÅ¿e things, eÅ¿pecially conÅ¿idering that we were not a meere mercinary Army, hired to Å¿erve any Arbitrary power of EÅ¿tate, but called forth and conjured by the Å¿everall Declarations of Parliament, for the defence of our owne and the peoples Rights and Liberties, and Å¿o we tooke up Armes in Judgement and conÅ¿cience to thoÅ¿e ends, and have Å¿o continued them, and are reÅ¿olved according to your firÅ¿t juÅ¿t deÅ¿ires in your Declarations, and Å¿uch principles as we have received from your frequent informations, and our owne common Å¿ence concerning thoÅ¿e our fundamentall Rights and Liberties, to effect and vindicate the juÅ¿t power and right of this Kingdome in Parliaments for thoÅ¿e common ends promiÅ¿ed againÅ¿t all Arbi â¢ rary power, violence and oppreÅ¿Å¿ion, and all particular parties or intereÅ¿ts whatÅ¿oever, the Å¿aid Declarations Å¿till directing us to the equita â¢ le Å¿ence of all Lawes and ConÅ¿titutions, as diÅ¿penÅ¿ing with the very letters of the Å¿ame, and being Å¿upreame to it, when the Å¿afety and preÅ¿ervation of all is concerned and aÅ¿Å¿uring us that all authority is fundamentally Å¿ealed in the Office, and but miniÅ¿terially in the PerÅ¿ons; neither do â¢ , or will theÅ¿e our proceedings (as we are fully and in conÅ¿cience perÅ¿waded) amount to any thing not warrantable before God and men, being thus farre much Å¿hort of the common proceedings in other Nations to things of an higher nature then we have yet appeared to; and we cannot but be Å¿enÅ¿ible of the great complplaints that have been made to us generally in the Kingdome from the people where we march, by Petition, and otherwiÅ¿e of ArbitrarineÅ¿Å¿e and injuÅ¿tice to their great and inÅ¿upportable oppresÅ¿ions.

And truly Å¿uch Kingdomes as have according both to the Law of Natu e and Nations, appeared to the vindication and defence of their â¢ uÅ¿t Rights and Liberties have proceeded much higher as our Brethren of Scotland, who in the firÅ¿t beginning of theÅ¿e late differences, aÅ¿Å¿ociated in Covenant from the very Å¿ame Grounds and Principles, having n â¢ viÅ¿ible forme either of Parliament or King to countenance
them & as they were therein inÅ¿tituted & protected by their own and this Kingdome alÅ¿o, Å¿o we juÅ¿tly Å¿hall expect to be.

We need not mention the State of the Nether-Lands, the Portugalls, and others, all proceeding upon the Å¿ame Principles of Right and Freedome, and accordingly the Parliament hath Declared it no reÅ¿iÅ¿ting of MajeÅ¿tracy to Å¿ide with the juÅ¿t Principles, and Law of Nature and Nations, being that Law upon which we have asÅ¿iÅ¿ted you, and that the Souldiery may lawfully hold the hands of that Generall who will turne his Cannon againÅ¿t his Army on purpoÅ¿e to deÅ¿troy them: the Seamen the hands of that Pilot who wilfully runs the Ship upon the rock (as our Brethren of
â¢â¢â¢ tland argued) and Å¿uch were the proceedings of our AnceÅ¿tors of famous memory, to the purchaÅ¿ing of Å¿uch Rights and Liberties as they have enjoyed through the price of their blood, and we both by that and the latter blood of our deareÅ¿t friends and fellow Souldiers, all the hazard of our owne doe lay claime unto.

Nor is that Å¿upreme end (the glory of God) wanting in theÅ¿e caÅ¿e; to Å¿et a price upon all Å¿uch proceedings of righteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e and juÅ¿tice, it being one witneÅ¿Å¿e of Go â¢ in the world to carry on a teÅ¿timony againÅ¿t the injuÅ¿tice and unrighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e of men, and againÅ¿t the miÅ¿carriages of Governments, when corrupted or declining from their primitive and originall glory.

TheÅ¿e things we mention but to compare proceedings, and to Å¿hew that we are Å¿o much the more juÅ¿tifiable and warrantable in what we do; by how much we come Å¿hort of that height and meaÅ¿ure of proceedings, which the people in free Kingdomes and Nations have formerly practiÅ¿ed.

Now having thus farre cleared our way in this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, we Å¿hall provide to propound Å¿uch things as we do humbly deÅ¿ire for the Å¿etling and Å¿ecuring of our owne and the Kingdomes peace and Å¿afety, as followeth:

1. That the HouÅ¿es may be Å¿peedily purged of Å¿uch Members, as for their Delinquency, or for corruptions or abuÅ¿e to the State, or undue election, ought not to Å¿it there; whereof the late election in Cornwall, Wales, and other parts of the Kingdome afford too many examples, to the great prejudice of the peoples freedome, in the Å¿aid Elections.

2. That thoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons who have in the late unjuÅ¿t and high proceedings againÅ¿t the Army, appeared to have the will, the confidence, credit, and power, to abuÅ¿e the Parliament and the Army, and indanger the Kingdome in the carrying on Å¿uch things againÅ¿t us (while an Army) may be Å¿ome way Å¿peedily diÅ¿abled from doing the like or worÅ¿e to us (who d sbanded and diÅ¿pearÅ¿t, and in the condition of private men) or to other the free borne people of England, in the Å¿ame condition with us: And that (for that purpoÅ¿e) the Å¿ame perÅ¿ons may not continue in the Å¿ame power (eÅ¿pecially) as our and the Kingdoms Iudges in the HigheÅ¿t TruÅ¿t, but may be made incapable thereof for future.

And if it be queÅ¿tioned who theÅ¿e are, we thought not fit â¢ articularly to name them in this our RepreÅ¿entation to you, but â¢â¢ all very Å¿peedily give in their names, and before long Å¿hall offer what we have to Å¿ay againÅ¿t them to your CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners: wherein we hope Å¿o to carry our Å¿elves, as that the world Å¿hall Å¿ee â¢ e aim at nothing of private revenge or animoÅ¿ities, but that Ju
â¢â¢ ice may have a free courÅ¿e, and the Kingdom be eaÅ¿ed and Å¿ecu
â¢ ed, by diÅ¿inabling Å¿uch men at leaÅ¿t from places of Judicature, who deÅ¿iring to advantage or Å¿et up themÅ¿elves and their party in a general confuÅ¿ion, have endeavored to put the Kingdom into a new flame of War, then which nothing is more abhorrent to us.

But becauÅ¿e neither the granting of theÅ¿e alone would be Å¿ufficient to Å¿ecure our own and the Kingdoms Right, Liberties and Safety, either for the preÅ¿ent Age or poÅ¿terity: Nor would our propoÅ¿al of this Å¿ingly be free from the Å¿candal and appearance of Faction or DeÅ¿ign onely to weaken one party (under the notion of unjuÅ¿t or tyrannical) that we may advance another which may be imagined more our own) We therefore Declare, That indeed we cannot but wiÅ¿h that Å¿uch men, and Å¿uch onely might be preferred to the great power and truÅ¿t of the Commonwealth, as are approved at leaÅ¿t for Moral RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿s; and of Å¿uch, we cannot but in our wiÅ¿hes prefer thoÅ¿e that appear acted thereunto by a principle of ConÅ¿cience and Religion in them: And accordingly we do and ever Å¿hall bleÅ¿s God for thoÅ¿e many Å¿uch Worthies, who through his providence have been choÅ¿en into this Parliament, and to Å¿uch mens endeavors under God) we cannot but attribute that Vindication in part of the peoples Rights and Liberties, and thoÅ¿e beginnings of a juÅ¿t Reformation, which the firÅ¿t proceedings of this Parliament appeared to have driven at and tended to, though of late obÅ¿tructed, or rather diverted to other ends and intereÅ¿ts, by the prevailing of other perÅ¿ons of other principles and conditions.

But yet we are Å¿o far from deÅ¿igning or complying to have an abÅ¿olute or Arbitrary power fixt or Å¿etled for continuance, in any perÅ¿ons whatÅ¿oever, as that (if we might be Å¿ure to obtain it) we cannot wiÅ¿h to have it Å¿o in the perÅ¿ons of any whom we could moÅ¿t confide in, or who Å¿hould appear moÅ¿t of our own
Opinions or Principles, or whom we might have perÅ¿onal aÅ¿Å¿urance of, or intereÅ¿t in; but we do and Å¿hall much rather wiÅ¿h, That the Authority of this Kingdom in Parliaments rightly conÅ¿tituted (that is) freely, equally and Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively choÅ¿en, according to its original intention, may ever Å¿tand and have its courÅ¿e. And therefore we Å¿hall apply our deÅ¿ires chiefly to Å¿uch things, as (by having Parliaments Å¿etled in Å¿uch a right conÅ¿titution) may give moÅ¿t hopes of JuÅ¿tice and RighteouÅ¿neÅ¿s to flow down equally to all in that its ancient channel, without any Overtures tending either to overthrow that foundation of Order and Government in this Kingdom, or to ingroÅ¿s that power for perpetuity into the hands of any particular perÅ¿ons or party whatÅ¿oever; and for that purpoÅ¿e, though as we have found it doubted by many men (minding Å¿incerely the publique good, but not weighing Å¿o fully all conÅ¿equences of things) it may, and is not unlike to prove, That upon the ending of this Parliament, and the Election of new, the conÅ¿titution of Å¿ucceeding Parliaments (as to the perÅ¿ons elected) may prove for the worÅ¿e many ways; yet Å¿ince neither in the preÅ¿ent purging of this Parliament, nor in the Election of new, we cannot promiÅ¿e to our Å¿elves or to the Kingdom an aÅ¿Å¿urance of JuÅ¿tice, or other poÅ¿itive good, from the hands of men, but thoÅ¿e who for preÅ¿ent appear moÅ¿t righteous and moÅ¿t for common good (having an unlimited power fixed in them during life or pleaÅ¿ure) in time may become corrupt, or Å¿ettle into parties or Factions; or on the other Å¿ide, in the caÅ¿e of new Elections, thoÅ¿e that Å¿hould Å¿o Å¿ucceed may prove as bad or worÅ¿e then the former: We therefore humbly conceive, That (of two inconveniences the leÅ¿s being to be choÅ¿en) the main things to be intended in this caÅ¿e (and beyond which humane providence cannot reach, as to any aÅ¿Å¿urance of poÅ¿itive good) Å¿eems to be this; viz. To provide, that however unjuÅ¿t or corrupt the perÅ¿ons of Parliament-men in preÅ¿ent or future may prove, or whatever ill they may do to particular parties, or to the whole in particular things, during their reÅ¿pective terms or periods, yet they Å¿hall not have the temptation or advantage of an unlimited power fixt in them during their own pleaÅ¿ures, whereby to perpetuate InjuÅ¿tice and OppreÅ¿Å¿ion upon any without end or remedy, or to advance and uphold any one particular
Party, Faction or IntereÅ¿t whatÅ¿oever, to the oppreÅ¿Å¿ion or prejudice of the Community, and the inÅ¿laving of the Kingdom unto all poÅ¿terity; but that theÅ¿e people may have an equal hope or poÅ¿Å¿ibility (if they have made an ill choice at one time to amend it in another) and themÅ¿elves may be in a capacity to taÅ¿te of Subjection aÅ¿wel as Rule, and may Å¿o be inclined to conÅ¿ider of other mens caÅ¿es, as what may come to be their own. This we Å¿peak as in relation to the HouÅ¿e of Commons, as being intruÅ¿ted on the peoples behalf for their intereÅ¿t in that great and Supreme power of the Commonwealth, (viz. The LegiÅ¿lative power, with the power of final Judgement) which being in its own nature Å¿o Arbitrary, and in a maner unlimited (unleÅ¿s in point of time) is moÅ¿t unfit and dangerous, as to the peoples intereÅ¿t, to be fixt in the perÅ¿ons of the Å¿ame men during life or their own pleaÅ¿ure; neither by the original conÅ¿titution of this State was it or ought it to continue Å¿o, nor do's it where ever it is and continue Å¿o, render that State any better then a meer Tyranny, or the people Å¿ubjected to it any better then VaÅ¿Å¿als; but in all States where there is any face of common Freedom, and particularly in this State of ENGLAND, as is moÅ¿t evident both by many PoÅ¿itive Laws (and Ancient conÅ¿tant CuÅ¿toms) the People have a Right to new and Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ive Elections unto that great and Supreme TruÅ¿t, at certain periods of time, which is Å¿o EÅ¿Å¿ential and Fundamental to their Freedom, as it cannot or ought not to be denied them or withheld from them, and without which the HouÅ¿e of Commons is of very little concernment to the IntereÅ¿t of the Commons of England: Yet in this we would not be miÅ¿underÅ¿tood, in the leaÅ¿t to blame thoÅ¿e Worthies of both HouÅ¿es, whoÅ¿e zeal to vindicate the Liberties of this Nation, did procure that Act for continuance of this Parliament, whereby it was Å¿ecured from being diÅ¿Å¿olved at the Kings pleaÅ¿ure, as former Parliaments have been, and reduced to Å¿uch a certainty as might enable them the better to aÅ¿Å¿ert and vindicate the Liberties of this Nation, immediately before Å¿o highly invaded, and then alÅ¿o Å¿o much indangered; and theÅ¿e we take to be the principal ends and grounds for which in that exigency of time and affairs it was promiÅ¿ed, and to which we acknowledge it hath happily been made uÅ¿e of: But we cannot
think it was by thoÅ¿e Worthies intended, or ought to be made uÅ¿e of, to the perpetuating of that Supreme TruÅ¿t and Power in the perÅ¿ons of any during their own pleaÅ¿ures, or to the debarring of the People from their right of Elections totally new, when thoÅ¿e Dangers or Exigencies were paÅ¿t, and the Affairs and Safety of the Common-wealth would admit of Å¿uch a change.

Having thus cleared our Grounds and Intentions, as we hope, from all Å¿cruples or miÅ¿underÅ¿tandings; in what follows we Å¿hall proceed further to propoÅ¿e, what we humbly deÅ¿ire for the Å¿etling and Å¿ecuring of our own and the Kingdoms Rights and Liberties (through the bleÅ¿Å¿ing of God to PoÅ¿terity) and therefore, upon all the grounds premiÅ¿ed, we further humbly deÅ¿ire as followeth:

3. That Å¿ome determinate period of time may be Å¿et, for the continuance of this and future Parliaments, beyond which none Å¿hall continue, and upon which new Writs may of courÅ¿e iÅ¿Å¿ue out, and new Elections Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ively take place, according to the intent of the Bill for Triennial Parliaments.

And herein we would not be miÅ¿underÅ¿tood, to deÅ¿ire a preÅ¿ent or Å¿udden diÅ¿Å¿olution of this Parliament, but onely (as is expreÅ¿Å¿ed before) That Å¿ome certain period may be Å¿et for the determining of it, Å¿o as it may not remain (as now) continuaile for ever, or during the pleaÅ¿ure of the preÅ¿ent Members: And we Å¿hould deÅ¿ire, That the period to be now Å¿et for ending this Parliament, may be Å¿uch as may give Å¿ufficient time for proviÅ¿ion of what is wanting, and neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be paÅ¿Å¿ed in point of JuÅ¿t Reformation, and for further Å¿ecuring the Rights, Liberties, and Å¿etling the Peace of the Kingdom; In order to which we further humbly offer:

4. That Å¿ecure proviÅ¿ion may be made for the continuance of future Perliaments, Å¿o as they may not be adjournable or diÅ¿Å¿olvable at the Kings pleaÅ¿ure, or any other ways, then by their own conÅ¿ent, during their reÅ¿pective periods, but at thoÅ¿e periods each Parliament to determine of courÅ¿e, as before: This we deÅ¿ire may be now provided for (if it may be) Å¿o as to put it out of all diÅ¿pute for future, though we think of right it ought not to have been otherwiÅ¿e before.

And thus a firm foundation being laid in the Authority and ConÅ¿titution of Parliament, for the hopes at leaÅ¿t of Common and Equal Right and Freedom to our Å¿elves, and all the Freeborn People of this Land; We Å¿hall for our parts freely and cheerfully commit our Å¿tock or Å¿hare of IntereÅ¿t in this Kingdom into this common Bottom of Parliaments; and though it may (for our particulars) go ill with us in one voyage, yet we Å¿hall thus hope (if right be with us) to fare better in another: TheÅ¿e things we deÅ¿ire may be provided for by Bill or Ordinance of Parliament, to which the Royal AÅ¿Å¿ent may be deÅ¿ired; and when His MajeÅ¿ty in theÅ¿e things, and what elÅ¿e Å¿hall be propoÅ¿ed by the Parliament, neceÅ¿Å¿ary for Å¿ecuring the Rights and Liberties of the People, and for Å¿etling the Militia and Peace of the Kingdom, Å¿hall have given his Concurrence, to put them paÅ¿t all diÅ¿pute; We Å¿hall then deÅ¿ire, That the Rights of His MajeÅ¿ty and His PoÅ¿terity may be conÅ¿idered of, and Å¿etled in all things, Å¿o far as may conÅ¿iÅ¿t with the Right and Freedom of the Subject, and with the Å¿ecurity of the Å¿ame for future.

That the large Powers given to Committees or Deputy Lieutenants, during the late times of War and DiÅ¿traction, may be Å¿peedily taken into conÅ¿ideration, That Å¿uch of thoÅ¿e Powers as appear not neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be continued, may be taken away, and Å¿uch of them as are neceÅ¿Å¿ary, be put into a regulated way, and left to as little ArbitraryneÅ¿s as the nature and neceÅ¿Å¿ity of the things wherein they are converÅ¿ant will bear.

That (publique JuÅ¿tice being firÅ¿t Å¿atisfied by Å¿ome few examples to PoÅ¿terity, out of the worÅ¿t of excepted perÅ¿ons and other Delinquents having paÅ¿t their compoÅ¿itions) Å¿ome courÅ¿e may be taken (by an Act of Oblivion or otherwiÅ¿e) whereby the Å¿eeds of future War or Fewds, either to the preÅ¿ent age or poÅ¿terity may the better be taken away, by eaÅ¿ing that Å¿ence of preÅ¿ent, and Å¿atisfying thoÅ¿e fears of future ruine or undoing to perÅ¿ons or families, which may drive men into any deÅ¿perate ways for Å¿elf-preÅ¿ervation or remedy; and by taking away the private remembrances and diÅ¿tinctions of parties, as far as may Å¿tand with Å¿afety to the Rights and Li â¢ erties we have hitherto fought for.

Wee have thus freely and clearly declared the depth and â¢ ottoms of our hearts & deÅ¿ires, in order to the Rights, Liberties, and Peace of the Kingdom; wherein we appeal to all men, whether we Å¿eek any thing of advantage to our Å¿elves, or any particular party what ever, to the prejudice of the whole; and whether the things we wiÅ¿h and Å¿eek, do not equally concern and conduce â¢ o the good of all in common, with our Å¿elves: According to the Å¿incerity of our deÅ¿ires and intentions, wherein (as we have â¢ lready found the concurrent Å¿ence of the people in divers Coun
